title: How to Polish Aluminum Valve Covers

steps.headline: Remove the cover from your vehicle and set it on a clean workstation.
steps.description: Prop open the hood of your vehicle and locate the big rectangular piece of aluminum that covers the valves. Undo the accelerator cable and PCV hose so they’re out of the way. Then, take a ratchet with a socket extension, undo the hardware on the cover, and wiggle it free. The accelerator cable is a metal braided cable that links the gas pedal to the engine. You can loosen it with a wrench. The PCV valve hose goes into the valve cover. You can usually loosen it by hand and then set it off to the side. Put the hardware in a magnetic bowl so you don’t lose any important pieces. If the valve cover seems stuck after you’ve taken out the bolts, use a hammer to gently tap it loose.Wear Your Protective Gear: Because you’ll be sanding down aluminum, it’s really important that you use a face shield or protective eyewear and a face mask to protect your eyes and lungs. You should also wear heavy work gloves and closed-toed shoes.

steps.headline: Use a clean rag to wipe away oil and grease from the valve cover.
steps.description: As you wipe down the valve cover, examine the rag. As it gets covered with oil, keep repositioning it so you’re using a clean section. If it gets fully saturated with grime, use additional clean rags until most of the visible grease is gone. If the valve cover is especially greasy, you may want to soak it in a degreasing product for 30 minutes before rinsing it off with clean water.

steps.headline: Sand the valve cover with 180-grit sandpaper.
steps.description: Depending on what kind of tools you have available, you can either use a manual sander or an electrically-powered orbital sander. Start with 180-grit sandpaper for a coarser finish to begin smoothing out the surface of the valve cover. Run the sandpaper over the surface 2-3 times until you can visually notice a difference in the texture of the cover. To get a great shine on the valve cover, you’ll use progressively finer and finer grits of sandpaper until the surface of the cover is shiny and smooth to the touch.Try an Alternative: If you don’t want to or don’t have the ability to sand the valve cover, you can use a piece of steel wool instead. It’ll take a lot of elbow grease, but it can be done! Scrub the entire valve cover over and over again with the steel wool until it is smooth to the touch.

steps.headline: Use 400-grit then 800-grit sandpaper to continue sanding the cover.
steps.description: Go over the valve cover 3-4 times with each grit of sandpaper until the aluminum is shiny and smooth. Run your hand over the valve cover—if you feel grittiness or rough bumps, keep sanding. Depending on how rusty and dirty the valve cover was to begin with, this could take anywhere from 20 minutes to 2 hours. Take breaks often to rest your hand so it doesn’t get cramped.

steps.headline: Sand the crevices so they match the body of the valve cover.
steps.description: Chances are, your manual sander or electric sander is too big to get into the small crevices where the hardware goes. You can use a small bevel sander to smooth out those parts, or you could use a smaller piece of sandpaper or steel wool to do it by hand. This makes the cover look nice and unified, but it also prevents rust from forming around the hardware once the valve cover is back in your vehicle.

steps.headline: Use a buffing wheel for a faster polishing process.
steps.description: A buffing wheel is an electric device that is used to polish all different kinds of metals. Use either a white rouge compound or blue all-purpose compound on the wheel for your aluminum valve cover. Turn the wheel on and gently move it back and forth over the surface of the valve cover. Continue doing this until the aluminum is shiny and reflective. If you haven’t used a buffing wheel and polishing compound before, the key is to apply a small quarter-sized amount of compound to the wheel and replace it often throughout the buffing process. You may be able to rent a buffing wheel from your local DIY store, or you could try to borrow one if you know somebody who works with metals.

steps.headline: Polish the valve cover by hand if you don’t have a buffing wheel.
steps.description: It’s super common to polish aluminum by hand, and all you’ll need is a microfiber cloth, aluminum polish, and some elbow grease. Apply a quarter-sized amount of the aluminum polish to the cloth, and gently rub it into the valve cover with small, circular motions. Repeat this over the surface of the cover until it is shiny and reflective. The polish gets absorbed into the aluminum as you buff it, which means it’ll continually get shinier and shinier. There are lots of great aluminum polishes to choose from. Both Mothers Aluminum Polish and Turtle Wax Metal Polish have great reviews, but you should always check out products and reviews for yourself before making a decision.

steps.headline: Get into the small crevices of the valve with a toothbrush.
steps.description: You may have been able to polish most of the crevices by hand, but chances are there were a few sections that were too small. Use a soft-bristled toothbrush and a small amount of aluminum polish to carefully go over each crevice so that they shine and match the body of the cover. Don’t use a toothbrush that is currently being used by somebody to brush their teeth. Have one that is specifically for use in the garage or shed so they don’t get mixed up.

steps.headline: Rinse the entire valve cover with soapy water to remove excess polish.
steps.description: Fill a bucket with warm water and 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of dish detergent. Dip a clean rag into the soapy water and wipe down the valve cover. Then, rinse the entire cover with clean water. If you have an outdoor hose, use that to fill up your bucket and rinse off the cover.

steps.headline: Dry the valve cover with a clean, soft microfiber cloth.
steps.description: Before replacing the valve cover, it needs to be totally dry. Pay special attention to the crevices and sections where the hardware goes. If you replace the cover while it’s still wet, it could rust. After wiping off the water, you could even leave the valve cover to continue air drying for a few hours just to ensure all the moisture is completely gone.

steps.headline: Replace the valve cover in your vehicle.
steps.description: Prop the hood of your vehicle back up and set the valve cover in place. Get the hardware that you removed previously and use your ratchet to screw in all the bolts. Reattach anything you had to detach to access the cover and then close the hood and you’re good to go! Taking care of your valve cover can save you a few hundred dollars in replacement costs, so it’s a worthwhile task.
